body:
You don't need the `...state` operator, as React will create the new state object on its own. E.g.

```this.setState(state => ({ ...state, expanded: !state.expanded }));```
is equivalent to
```this.setState({ expanded: !this.state.expanded });```
(especially in this case, where `expanded` is the only property in state)
body_html:
You don't need the ...state operator, as React will create the new state object on its own. E.g.

this.setState(state => ({ ...state, expanded: !state.expanded }));
is equivalent to
this.setState({ expanded: !this.state.expanded });
(especially in this case, where expanded is the only property in state)
